description: The "dd" in Welsh corresponds in sound to the "th" in mither, and English also has moider and moither.

verbs.description: mither (third-person singular simple present mithers, present participle mithering, simple past and past participle mithered)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Northern England, especially Manchester) To make an unnecessary fuss, moan, bother.
(transitive, Northern England, especially Manchester) To pester or irritate someone.

description: Variant from Middle English muther, muthir, from Old English mōdor (“mother”). More at mother.
